pico.title: Federated Learning for Satellite Image Classification: A Scoping Review
pico.population: Multi-source satellite imagery datasets held by different organizations including space agencies (ESA, NASA, JAXA), commercial providers (Planet, Maxar, Airbus), national mapping agencies, and research institutions, covering applications such as land cover classification, object detection, change monitoring, and disaster response
pico.intervention: Federated learning approaches enabling collaborative model training without sharing raw imagery, including horizontal federated learning, vertical federated learning, federated transfer learning, and privacy-enhanced variants with differential privacy or secure aggregation
pico.comparison: Centralized training with pooled data, transfer learning from publicly available pre-trained models, independent training without collaboration, and traditional data sharing agreements
pico.outcome: Model accuracy and performance metrics (F1, IoU, mAP), communication efficiency (bandwidth requirements, convergence speed), privacy preservation (data leakage risk, gradient inversion attack resistance), scalability across heterogeneous sensors and resolutions, and practical deployment feasibility
pico.research_question: For satellite imagery classification tasks involving multiple data holders, how do federated learning approaches compare to centralized training and independent training in achieving model accuracy while preventing raw data exposure and enabling cross-organizational collaboration?
pico.rationale: Earth observation data is distributed across numerous organizations with varying data sharing restrictions due to commercial interests, national security concerns, and licensing constraints. Federated learning offers a paradigm where collaborative AI model development can occur without centralizing sensitive imagery. As EO-based AI applications expand, understanding the effectiveness, limitations, and practical requirements of federated approaches is critical for space agencies, commercial providers, and research consortia seeking to leverage collective data assets while respecting data governance constraints.

sub_questions.title: Accuracy Comparison Across Federation Scenarios
sub_questions.population: Satellite image classification tasks with data distributed across 3-10 organizations
sub_questions.intervention: Federated averaging (FedAvg) and variants (FedProx, FedBN) for satellite imagery
sub_questions.comparison: Centralized training baseline with equivalent total data volume
sub_questions.outcome: Classification accuracy gap, convergence rounds required, performance on heterogeneous vs. homogeneous data distributions
sub_questions.research_question: What is the accuracy gap between federated learning and centralized training for satellite image classification, and how does data heterogeneity across organizations affect this gap?

sub_questions.title: Privacy Guarantees in EO Federated Learning
sub_questions.population: Federated learning systems processing satellite imagery with sensitive content (infrastructure, defense, commercial assets)
sub_questions.intervention: Privacy-enhanced federated learning (differential privacy, secure aggregation, gradient compression)
sub_questions.comparison: Standard federated averaging without privacy enhancements
sub_questions.outcome: Resistance to gradient inversion attacks, membership inference attack success rate, formal privacy guarantees (epsilon values achieved), accuracy trade-off
sub_questions.research_question: How effective are privacy-enhancing techniques in protecting sensitive satellite imagery during federated learning, and what accuracy costs do they impose?

sub_questions.title: Cross-Sensor Federation
sub_questions.population: Multi-sensor satellite datasets (optical, SAR, multispectral, hyperspectral) held by different organizations
sub_questions.intervention: Federated learning approaches handling sensor heterogeneity (vertical FL, multi-modal federation)
sub_questions.comparison: Single-sensor federated learning, sensor-specific independent models
sub_questions.outcome: Multi-sensor fusion accuracy, handling of missing modalities, transfer across sensor types
sub_questions.research_question: How do federated learning approaches perform when federating across heterogeneous satellite sensor types compared to single-sensor federation?
